title: Hi, I’m Amol.
text:
Hi, I’m Amol.
I am a Research-to-Product Technologist working at the intersection of AI, product, and real-world deployment. I specialize in taking advanced research from the lab and turning it into scalable, production-grade systems.
Currently, I’m an Applied AI Scientist at the Ellison Institute of Technology (EIT), Oxford. My career has been defined by a “bench-to-bits” trajectory. Starting in physical lab science and evolving into software engineering and AI research at institutions like IBM Research, AstraZeneca, and Pfizer.

What I Build
I thrive in high-growth, ambiguous environments where technical and product decisions are tightly coupled. Over the past decade, I have focused on building AI that survives contact with reality:

ML-Driven Organic Synthesis: Delivered AiZynthFinder, an open-source platform that influenced how medicines are made at AstraZeneca, and IBM RXN which impacted how agrochemicals are developed at Syngenta.
Applied LLMs: Developed and trained LLMs for text-to-SQL to bridge the gap between natural language and complex data architectures.
Computer Vision & IoT: Built automatic activity recognition systems to digitize real-world laboratory and operational workflows.



My Approach
My strength lies in translation. I bridge the gap between research, engineering, and user needs. I have led small teams, driven internal initiatives, and owned client-facing engagements across pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and finance.
I’m most engaged when I can own the full lifecycle. From the first line of research code to the design, deployment, and productionisation of a system.
I am interested in roles and collaborations where building, scaling, and high-velocity impact matter.


Beyond the Lab
When I’m not building systems, I’m usually pushing my physical limits in the mountains or the water. My background in endurance and alpine sports includes:

Cycling & Swimming: Cycled solo from Zurich to Istanbul, completed a Half Ironman, and finished a 10km marathon swim.
Alpinism: Active in ski touring, mountaineering, and climbing, including several alpine summits (not as much anymore, South East England is pretty flat)

I find that the discipline and risk management required for these pursuits mirror the persistence and focus needed to solve high-stakes technical problems.

title: Publications
text:
My research has focused on the digitisation of chemistry. Bridging the gap between the virtual and physical worlds, by integrating AI, cloud computing, robotics, and advanced computing technologies to accelerate scientific discovery.

title: Amol Thakkar
text:
orcid = '0000-0003-0403-406' # Fill your orcid here


import requests

We use the /works api to list all works related to the orcid. This gives a summary of all works, so citation information is not included. We collect the put-code of all works to retrieve the citation information later.

response = requests.get('https://pub.orcid.org/v3.0/{}/works'.format(orcid),
                        headers={"Accept": "application/orcid+json" })
record = response.json()


record

{'response-code': 404,
 'developer-message': '404 Not Found: The resource was not found.',
 'user-message': 'The resource was not found.',
 'error-code': 9016,
 'more-info': 'https://members.orcid.org/api/resources/troubleshooting'}



put_codes = []
for work in record['group']:
    put_code = work['work-summary'][0]['put-code']
    put_codes.append(put_code)
put_code = put_codes[0]


---------------------------------------------------------------------------
KeyError                                  Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[4], line 2
      1 put_codes = []
----> 2 for work in record['group']:
      3     put_code = work['work-summary'][0]['put-code']
      4     put_codes.append(put_code)

KeyError: 'group'



We use the /<orcid>/work/<put-code> endpoint to retrieve the citation information for each record.

citations = []
for put_code in put_codes:
    response = requests.get('https://pub.orcid.org/v3.0/{}/work/{}'.format(orcid, put_code),
                            headers={"Accept": "application/orcid+json" })
    work = response.json()
    if work['citation'] is not None:
        citations.append(work['citation']['citation-value'])


with open('output.bib', 'w') as bibfile:
    for citation in citations:
        bibfile.write(citation)
        bibfile.write('\n')

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
text:
Chemical synthesis remains one of the most knowledge-intensive and execution-constrained processes in science. Despite major advances in computational chemistry and machine learning, synthesis planning and execution are still dominated by manual reasoning, brittle procedures, and poorly captured experimental knowledge.
My work has focused on automating chemical synthesis end-to-end — from reasoning about how molecules can be made, to building systems that connect planning, execution, and learning in real laboratory environments. This case study traces that work across academic research, open tooling, and deployed industrial systems.

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
text:
The Problem
Synthesis planning does not scale.
Across both academic and industrial settings, the same limitations recur:

Synthetic routes are evaluated heuristically, not systematically

Experimental knowledge is fragmented across notebooks, instruments, and individuals

Failed experiments are rarely captured in a way that enables learning

Translating research ideas into reliable, repeatable systems is slow

As a result, synthesis remains difficult to reproduce, hard to optimize, and resistant to automation.

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
section: Origins: From Bench Chemistry to Systems Thinking
text:
Origins: From Bench Chemistry to Systems Thinking
My initial training was in experimental and computational chemistry. Across projects in synthesis, catalysis, enzymology, and electronic structure theory, I repeatedly encountered the same friction points: slow iteration cycles, sensitivity to poorly documented conditions, and limited transferability of synthetic knowledge.
Representative prior work included:

Multi-step synthesis of complex heterocycles

Catalytic studies of iron-doped zeolites for alkane dehydrogenation

Conversion of renewable feedstocks into unnatural amino acids and cyclopeptides

Diastereoselective reductive amination via rhodium-catalyzed transfer hydrogenation

Density functional theory studies of reactive inorganic systems

Investigation of enzymatic chemical transformations

These experiences motivated a shift away from optimizing individual reactions toward building systems that could reason about synthesis at scale.

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
text:
Research Foundations: AiZynthFinder
This motivation led to work on AiZynthFinder, an open-source retrosynthesis planning framework designed to make synthesis planning more systematic, interpretable, and accessible.
Key contributions included:

Reaction Dataset Analysis
Systematic analysis of public reaction datasets to identify structural biases, coverage gaps, and failure modes that impact model behavior and evaluation.


RingBreaker
Targeted retrosynthetic capabilities for ring-forming reactions, addressing transformations that generic template-based methods struggled to recover.


RAScore
A learned feasibility score to rapidly prioritize synthesizable routes early in the search process, improving both efficiency and relevance.


Interactive Synthesis Exploration
Browser-based tools that enabled chemists to explore retrosynthetic space interactively, lowering the barrier between algorithmic planning and human intuition.
Outcome:
AiZynthFinder became widely adopted in academic research and served as a foundation for subsequent work on scalable synthesis planning.

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
section: From Research to Product: IBM RXN
text:
From Research to Product: IBM RXN
At IBM, this work progressed from research prototypes to production-grade systems supporting real users and workflows.
Key areas of contribution included:

Disconnection-Aware Retrosynthesis
Improved alignment between algorithmic planning and chemist reasoning by explicitly modeling disconnection strategies.


NLP for Template Extraction
Applied natural language processing to automate reaction template extraction, reducing reliance on manual curation.


Template Fingerprints
Developed compact representations for reaction rules, enabling similarity search and clustering over large template libraries.


NLP-Driven Data Curation
Used language models to improve the structure, consistency, and usability of reaction data, supporting reproducibility and downstream learning.
Outcome:
These efforts supported the deployment of retrosynthesis capabilities in IBM RXN, bridging the gap between academic methods and usable industrial tools.

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
section: Toward Closed-Loop Systems: The Lab That Learns
text:
Toward Closed-Loop Systems: The Lab That Learns
As synthesis planning systems matured, a fundamental limitation became clear: planning alone does not enable learning from execution.
At IBM Research, this motivated work toward the Lab That Learns — an initiative focused on connecting design, execution, and data capture into closed-loop experimental systems.
Rather than relying on manual documentation, the Lab That Learns explores the use of multimodal foundation models to automatically capture and structure experimental workflows using video, audio, text, and instrument signals. This enables:

Automated documentation of experimental procedures

Structured, queryable experimental records

Analysis of execution patterns across experiments

Learning from both successful and failed runs

In this context, retrosynthesis planning becomes one component of a broader system that learns from real laboratory execution, rather than a standalone prediction tool.
More details on the project are available from IBM Research:
https://research.ibm.com/projects/lab-that-learns

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
section: Unifying Theme: Formalizing Synthesis for Execution
text:
Unifying Theme: Formalizing Synthesis for Execution
Across research tools, production systems, and laboratory automation, the underlying challenge has remained consistent:

Synthesis knowledge is implicit, fragmented, and difficult to operationalize.

This work focused on making that knowledge explicit — through representations, planning algorithms, human-in-the-loop interfaces, and execution-aware systems — in order to support reproducibility, scalability, and continuous improvement.

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
text:
Impact

Peer-reviewed publications in retrosynthesis and computational chemistry

Open-source tools adopted by academic researchers

Deployed retrosynthesis systems used in industrial settings

Contributions to closed-loop laboratory research initiatives

Links to publications, code, products, and press are provided separately.

title: Case Study: Automating Chemical Synthesis
text:
Why This Matters
Automating chemical synthesis is not just a modeling challenge. It requires systems that connect reasoning, execution, and learning in the physical world.
This work demonstrates how ideas can progress from theoretical insight to open tools, deployed products, and experimental learning systems — with synthesis planning as a central, enabling component.
